reviews.cons: The workflow can be really up and down and the pay is low (40-50k average). To be fair, the pay is generally low in this industry, but this isn't a place you can stay long-term if you want a real liveable income
reviews.pros: The people are amazing, the product/mission is something that actually matters and that the company genuinely cares about and believes in - there are tons of awesome perks (free travel, great benefits, unlimited sick days, 3 weeks vacation in your first year) - lots of opportunities for social & professional development, and they've managed to stay pretty stable through the pandemic
reviews.summary: Great Place to Work, Low Pay

reviews.advice: Spend some cash on increasing the head count, free up needed resources and ditch entrenched management causing problems with high turnover resulting in wasted resources, skills and knowledge loss.
reviews.cons: Open plan office gets noisy at times, pay is average to poor, bonus system is not transparent, high workload and severely understaffed and poorly resourced. High turnover due to poorly experienced and entrenched middle management.
reviews.pros: Diverse and talented people from interesting backgrounds, great office location, massive scale of operations, opportunities to vary work duties and areas.
reviews.summary: Potential to be great but entrenched management is retarding company growth and employee job satisfaction.

reviews.advice: Listen to your staff and don't be afraid to engage with them. Even if you can't solve the problem right away, a little one-on-one time makes us and our issues feel valued—and that's all we need to stay motivated.
reviews.cons:
The entrepreneurial, "get it done" mentality also means that sometimes structure and order fall to the wayside and come in #2 (or #4... or #14... or #99). Roles can go ambiguous or undefined, with the onus on the employee to figure out exactly what it is they're supposed to prioritize. Managers are cool and generally supportive, but don't offer too much direction on a day-to-day basis. Taking matters into your own hands sometimes means that you will have wasted time on something nobody is going to use—which is why networking and listening are key skills to develop within the company. 

If you're a newbie to EF, it'll take 1 or 2 years to get used to how things work and know intuitively who to ask for this-and-that. This kind of company might not work for those looking for something structured, with a familiar corporate hierarchy—one reason the turnover is so high. Corporate mentorships don't exist at all; it's on you to find your own mentor. My word of advice if you're looking to get hired by EF: make sure that you know someone WELL within the company before doing so. A friend at the beginning of your time here will help you get acquainted with all of this company's quirks double-time and cut down on the time you spend dazed and confused; he or she will be infinitely more helpful than a mentor will be.
reviews.pros: I work in a creative department at EF. While I wouldn't say that good ideas are rewarded, taking ACTION is. This is the kind of place that acclaims doers, not thinkers; we're constantly working on big and small ticket items. It's the kind of place that keeps you busy. If you are self-motivated and have a positive attitude, it's a great place to thrive. People are not nasty or uber-competitive; most are generally supportive and easy-going. Material benefits are good; health and dental are covered, vacation days are generous, you get to travel, and if you're an expat, you get one trip home a year on the house.
reviews.summary: You'd better like it fast and messy: proactivity and action are rewarded in a disorganized environment at EF

reviews.cons: Very corporate (for-profit private school, kind of strange to my American sensibilities). There's a fair amount of corporate B.S. as a result. Health benefits are mediocre, retirement benefits non-existent. They're not counting on you staying on indefinitely, and in fact turnover is very high in my experience.
reviews.pros: Excellent recruitment, onboarding, visa processing, and training. Students are a lot of fun to work with. There are plenty of friendly colleagues and lots of Westerners across the city. Salary is quite good for FOB teachers, and if you're interested there are plenty of opportunities for advancement.
reviews.summary: Good place to work in China.

reviews.advice:
This review is driven by disappointment, not vengeance.  

Re-interview some of the directors and management as the majority have no idea what they are doing. They spend all day walking, talking and eating as they feel safe in their jobs due to it being given to them for the sole reason of being friends or family with the people dictating who to employ for these roles. 

Stop hiring and promoting people that add no value and start hiring the people you need. It is such a shame that a company that could be great simply has no motivation to be so. It is a toxic environment to work with bullying, corruption, harassment, nepotism and a seriously poor levels of management and humane capabilities. I urge any possible joiners to think twice and to try and understand what you think you will get out of this career move.
reviews.cons:
Far too many managers and directors with a lack of drive and skills, who just enjoy their salaries without working a day in their lives. You will see them laughing and chatting together, having their coffees and snacks all day, walking the corridors with their laptops in hand pretending they actually have somewhere to be and something to do. The joke is to book a meeting room and just go there to take a nap. No one will ever question anything you do because no one really cares. 

Another issue in EF is that it will not matter how good you are at what you do or what you are capable of unless you are friends or family of management. You will not advance and all the jobs are given based on who you know and how good you are at not questioning, not bothering, not caring all that much. The goal is to look busy enough that no one will call up on you and at the same time keep to yourself whenever you see something you can change or that you conceive is wrong. Silence and complicity will get you to the top in EF, not commitment and development. 

Unfortunately, this leads the majority of the employees in charge of the different teams' progress being utterly useless and idle. This is affecting the company's trajectory and it has gone from a profit multiplying company to a sinking ship as the majority of management lacks the intelligence and drive required for their job. A good ethical person will quit as soon as they understand their efforts are in vain, people will join EF thinking it is a big company and will blindly give themselves to overtime (not paid), multiple business trips, unnecessary meetings while they are “under the spell” i.e. while they believe they can make a difference and change something. As soon as the 2 to 3 years mark hits, it is like a fog lifting from the air and the good ones will either burn-out and leave or they will just leave to travel for months on end to cleanse their soul. 

With all this, the environment has become toxic as the higher ups do not work but expect a wage, resulting in the exploitation of lower paid staff (usually just out of college kids) that must cover excessive workloads generated by poor organisation. You will be expected to sit in front of a computer screen for hours on end and managers and trainees will end up spending anywhere from 2-6 hours at a time in front of a computer screen. It is frowned upon to actually take your breaks and arrive and leave on time, this will convey the message that you do not go the “extra mile”; even your own peers will judge you as they are too scared to disagree with the puppet directors. 

Finally, the majority of higher roles are filled in with people that are unable to speak English properly, and in an international market, this is essential.
reviews.pros:
Meet a lot of people from different backgrounds and cultures
Good opportunities to network with external partners
Bling Bling parties and after work gatherings to distract the easily impressed just-out-of-college folks
reviews.summary: This review is driven by disappointment, not vengeance. EF can do much better.

reviews.advice: I would not presume to advise the management on any issue, but I do hope that the kids platform is fully rolled out quite soon.
reviews.cons:
Online teaching is not quite as much fun as working in a real classroom.

Punishments, such as a reduction in scheduling priority, for breaking the rules e.g. deleting schedules so you can do better paid work for another company, are administered silently. You are not notified of specifically what you did wrong, how much you are being punished or for how long.

Responses via Contact Us are often disinterested and occasionally quite rude.

The variable pay day from the 16th to the 25th of month is pretty unbearable. Some online platforms are able to pay on the 15th every month. Others pay weekly.

The evaluation system means that anything less than a five-star evaluation or no evaluation is bad news. A bad tempered student can smash your evaluation average with one hit, without having to explain themselves.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your feedback. Happy to hear you enjoy working as an online teacher and we as well hope for the platform to be rolled out shortly. Best regards,

reviews.pros:
I moved to this job from being a classroom teacher as my last employer didn't pay my wages for four months. English Online constituted more stable employment, a better rate of pay and the end of unpaid work (marking exams, lesson planning, data entry).

It took 6-8 months to feel really comfortable with it, but since then I've felt very comfortable in the online classroom. The pattern of teaching for 40-45 minutes and having the rest of the hour to complete an evaluation form is sustainable. Other online platforms offer much shorter breaks, and the accumulated stress takes its toll eventually, even if they pay a bit better.

I am able to develop good relationships with one-on-one students, sometimes up to 100 classes over more than a year. It is difficult to get that kind of student loyalty working as an independent teacher.

Teachers are paid via Payoneer, which works well. I am able to send money to my bank account in my home country or the country where I live. Payoneer seems to charge for currency exchange but not for a simple transaction in USD. It may be a good idea to set up your own Payoneer account before you add English Live as a payee, in order to have the full range of payment options.

A few times, I have tried to move to other platforms and it didn't work out. English Live has allowed me to return to my old job on each occasion.

reviews.cons: Variety in the times you can teach, like teaching in the evenings or afternoons

employerResponses.response:
Thanks for such a positive review! 
We love to hear that you enjoy the flexibility, that you’re happy with our teaching platform and the pay. 
Due to student demographics, we do have limited hours where classes can be booked, and this is completely controlled by student demand. We understand that these hours won’t be attractive for everyone, but hope that like you, people will continue to focus on the positives.
Thanks again!

reviews.pros:
+ Flexibility!! you are able to pick your own hours and you only have to work in the mornings!! so you can get on with the rest of your day

+The online teaching platform is really easy to use!! All the content is there and how to approach the lesson, little preparation is needed!!

+ Not such a bad pay too!! You get paid  a lot more than people in other types of part time jobs!!

+ Lovely and respectful students!!

reviews.advice: Work on communication issues. Adapt the summer course so that it is easier on students and teachers. Pay teachers a little more (especially those living in more expensive areas). Don’t put profit before student wellbeing. Take mental and physical health into consideration.
reviews.cons:
- The salary is quite low in comparison to other jobs, especially in your first year when paying off the housing loan. While I was earning less than 12,000 yuan (£1340) per month, I was constantly seeing friends and former colleagues getting paid 20,000 + for the same job at other schools. 

- Poor communication is a big problem at EF. Often we would be told we had to attend trainings or teach classes with minimal notice. The language barrier between foreign and local staff could also be frustrating. Some members of the sales team had very poor English which made it difficult to convey messages to them and ask for their help unless we could speak Chinese, which the vast majority of foreign teachers cannot. 

- Our free time was often not taken into consideration. As I previously mentioned, last minute trainings or events could be scheduled whenever the company felt like it and we just had to oblige, regardless of if we had already made plans or even if it was our day off. Once I was handed a written warning because I refused to attend a training that was being held not only on my day off but on my birthday. Sometimes it feels like we are seen as teaching machines rather than human beings.

- The ‘summer course’, where we work 6 days a week teaching additional courses on top of regular courses, is a terrible experience. The little free time we have left on our one day off is spent recovering from the exhausting work schedule of endless classes. This goes on for almost two months during the summer period. I noticed not only is it exhausting for teachers, but the students would become tired of wasting their whole summer holiday in the classroom rather than spending it with family and friends. After this experience, I decided I would leave the following year before having to go through it again.

- They are obsessed with money, sales and retention. The thing about training centres is they are not proper schools, they are businesses. Their goal is to make profit and to retain students in order to continue making profit. This often comes at the expense of teachers, sales staff, and the students themselves. We would be told to place students in classes too difficult for them out of scheduling convenience or because parents wouldn’t pay if their kids weren’t placed in the highest grade possible.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your candid feedback. We are glad to hear you’ve had a rewarding experience, both at work with your students and colleagues and outside with your travels. Effective communication is especially important when working with different teams. Therefore, it is unfortunate to hear there were some challenges with this. With respect to Summer courses, in addition to contracted salary, teachers receive a bonus based on the amount of Summer courses they teach. We will continue to work to improve our communication. Thank you for reaching out, we appreciate your feedback.

jobTitle.text: English As A Second Language Teacher

reviews.pros:
- The students. It is very rewarding getting to teach such a wide age range of kids; you will spend one day teaching 3 year olds their ABCs and the next will be debating international politics and environmental crises with teenagers. Some might not like this disparity but I loved it. Variety and constant change is something I need in the workplace and EF can provide that.

- Making friends from across the world is something you can’t do in most workplaces, but working as an English teacher abroad I made friends from the US and UK, Canada, South Africa, Russia, Poland, New Zealand, and many other countries. The expat scene is China is a rich and diverse melting pot which I was grateful to be a part of.

- During weekdays you have a significant amount of free time  since the work day is only from 3-8.30pm. You can do whatever you want during the morning and early afternoon. Weekends are not so fun since you’re working from 9am-6.30pm it not longer due to unfinished admin. Despite that, I found myself with plenty of free time to lie in, exercise, explore the city, study Chinese and have coffee with friends. 

- China is a great place to be if you want to see Asia. Flights to countries such as Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia are very cheap, so within a year you can travel so several different countries without running out of cash.

- It is a unique and life changing experience. Moving to the other side of the world and mingling with such a diverse group of people is a memorable experience that I won’t regret doing. While the company has it’s flaws, I would still recommend doing this for a short time, thought would not want to stay longer than a year.
reviews.summary: A unique and challenging experience with many big ups and downs.

reviews.advice:
Do more than just a little bit better than minimum.
Care about your staff. Not just about P&L.
Pay your staff better. Everyone, inside and outside EF, knows EF pays very low -- and do not insult our intelligence by saying "we are constantly evaluating our salary to stay competitive", as if we do not have friends outside EF, do not know recruitiers, do not know the market rate.
Be transparent in your communication. Talk about the tough things, answer the tough questions rather than "How do you releive stress?". This is exceedingly important now with the social change that is happening in the world. People are sick of companies smiling while their employees suffer.
reviews.cons:
Forced "positive" attitude and intransparent communication, means a lot of issues and complaints are swept under the rug. "Difficult" mesages are not communicated, even if they are important, many things must be found out through rumours and gossip (or through the news!).
Horrible handling of covid times:
- People put on kurzarbeit to save the company money despite the fact that their workload increased -- therefore, many workers (including middle management) had to work 'secretly' on weekends and outside their hours.
- Home office not allowed until a few days before Federal Gov enforced it back in March. 
- After reopening the office in the fall, the upper management told people that you either must come to the office full time, or work from home full time. You cannot spend some days in the office and some days at home. The implication was that we would stay at home on Friday/Monday to get a longer weekend. This is poor treatment of staff, who have worked 5+ months independently at home, worked longer hours (even in the case of kurzarbeit), and got more responsibilities.
- Working from office encouraged up until the day after Fed Gov recommended otherwise in Oct -- despite rising cases both in Zurich and within the office.
- Constantly told by owners and top management that our priorities are with our customers. This is what we are paid to do, we know, but please show compassion to your employees who are also worried about their own health.

Low pay. No 13th month salary, no bonuses for non-sales staff despite "best year ever!". 
5 days "extra" vacation days to compensate for over time -- basically, you are asked to do unlimited unpaid overtime as needed.
Low benefits, non-existent during covid times.
Clear bias in favor of Swedish people
Flat structure so no way to move up on the ladder. Yet decisions come from a couple top management people, middle management cannot stand up for their teams.
No HR, only Payroll Department which will tell you "you should discuss with your manager". No one to go to for complaints, especially if your problem is with your manager. Problems anyway are smiled away due to the forced positiveness of EF.
reviews.pros:
International environment
Energetic teammates
Gym in the office (closed during covid)
Company parties every month (pre-covid)
reviews.summary: Poor treatment of staff, low salary
